bibl.title: Letter from William F. King to John J. Moran, June 22, 1933

div1.p: King invites Moran to participate in a meeting of the American Public Health Association commemorating the anniversary of Walter Reed's paper, presented in 1900.

div1.head: Letter from William F. King to John J. Moran, June 22, 1933

October 9-12, 1933
June 22, 1933.
Mr. John J. Moran,
Care of Cia Sunoco de Cuba,
Ave Menocal No. 102-A,
Havana, Cuba.
Dear Sir:-
div1.p:
In connection with the annual meeting
of the American Public Health Association to be held in Indianapolis
October 9th to 12th, 1933, we are planning to hold a public Memorial
Session to commemorate the work done by Walter Reed and his associates
in Havana, Cuba, and to honor all those who participated in the yellow
fever experiments. We are desirous of having as many of the survivors
of these experiments as can to attend this Memorial Session, and to
have a message from all survivors who cannot attend, to be read at the
Session.

We are asking the Surgeon General of the
Army, Robert U. Patterson, to make the principal address at this
Memorial meeting. We feel it is especially fitting that this meeting
shall be held in Indianapolis because Major General Reed made the first
official announcements of the Havana experiments at the meeting of the
American Public Health Association in Indianapolis in 1900. Now that
the American Public Health Association is coming back to Indianapolis for
the first time since 1900, we feel that the Association will honor itself
by recalling the address of Walter Reed in Indianapolis in 1900 and by
honoring all those who has a part in the momentous work carried out
in Havana.

There is a further reason for having such a
Memorial Session at Indianapolis in the fact that John R. Kissinger, a
survivor of those who volunteered in Havana, lives in Hunting,
Indiana, so that the Memorial Session will become in part an Indiana
tribute to one of its own citizens.

This Memorial Session will be held on Tuesday
evening, October 10th, 1933.

The American Public Health Association and the
Indianapolis Committee in charge of the Indianapolis Meeting is extending
to you a most cordial invitation to attend the Memorial Session at
Indianapolis. It if is impossible for you to attend this meeting, we
will be glad to have a message from you, a few words of greeting,
something personal concerning yourself, or concerning your experience
at Havana, or whatever you may wish to convey to those in attendance
at the meeting. Your message will be read as a part of the program
